Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Cross-Disciplinary Investigations in Imaging and Image Analyses

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: This proposal requests funding for a two-day workshop on cross-disciplinary investigations in imaging and image analysis. This workshop will bring together representatives from US and foreign academic institutions representing a variety of disciplines engaged in imaging and imaging analyses. The workshop envisions large-group keynote presentations by prominent researchers and break-out sessions on specific topical areas. One goal of the meeting is to facilitate education, training and informational exchange among multiple scientific disciplines including humanities, arts, social science, science, and computational researchers to address related research challenges for which image and imaging analysis is both a means and end (visualization, virtual spaces, et al.) The organizations planning the event include the National Center for Supercomputing Applications (NCSA), the University of Illinois School of Art and Design, and the Institute for Computing in Humanities, Arts, and Social Science (I-CHASS) as well as individual stakeholders in the broader community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
1           Abstract

Designed to facilitate information exchange education and training among several scientific disciplines, the workshop “Cross-Disciplinary Investigations in Imaging and Image Analyses” brought together representatives from academic institutions in the United States and abroad, as well as from American museums and other archives. Humanists, social scientists, artists, and archivists were paired with computer scientists and information technology specialists at the workshop in order to present complementary views on topics related to imaging and image analyses of historical artifacts.

The workshop was organized as collaboration between the National Center for Supercomputing Applications (NCSA), the Institute for Computing in Humanities, Arts, and Social Science (I-CHASS), the University of Illinois’ School of Art and Design, and the Center for Digital Humanities (CDH) at the University of South Carolina. It took place at the NCSA facility in Urbana, Illinois on April 1-2, 2011. The main workshop organizers were: Peter Bajcsy, NCSA, Univ. of Illinois; Jenifer Guiliano, CDH, Univ. of South Carolina; Kevin Hamilton, School of Art and Design, UIUC; and Simon Appleford, ICHASS, Univ. of Illinois.

2           Workshop Execution

Cross-Disciplinary Investigations in Imaging and Image Analyses brought together multi-disciplinary stakeholders in the burgeoning field of imaging and image analysis to offer a unique opportunity for cross-collaboration and information-exchange through the use of computational techniques to bridge humanities, arts, and social science research. During a two-day workshop, it covered topics including: 2D scanning technologies, 2D and 3D imaging and analysis, content-based image and video retrieval, and preservation strategies. The workshop created opportunities for the humanities, arts, social science and archival communities to explore scientific instruments applied to imaging historical artifacts, as well as opportunities for the scientific community to investigate the adaptation of existing web 2.0 technologies to distributed research. The major activities of the project were focused on designing the workshop theme, announcing the workshop and soliciting contributions, managing workshop contributions and registration, performing local arrangements for the workshop, moderating the workshop sessions and round table sessions, providing audio-visual support and recording the workshop, preparing workshop surveys and processing obtained feedback, and summarizing the workshop findings in the final report.

3           Summary of Workshop Outcomes

Our research findings are in the information obtained from the workshop participants about domain specific technical challenges in dealing with digital artifacts, and about the challenges of multi-disciplinary collaborations. Key to our discussions during the workshop was a revelation of the different emphases and approaches to similar processing problems, across the domains of commercial, non-profit, and educational research. Distinctions between work with 2-D, 3-D or time-based artifacts seemed less important than did distinctions between which stage of processing most interested each researcher. For some, the content of the research lies in acquisition of data, such as the problem of discerning 3-D models of historical buildings from old maps and image scans of texts.
